newsitem.title: USA: Calif. agency signs deal for $1.2 bln transit plan.
newsitem.headline: Calif. agency signs deal for $1.2 bln transit plan.

text.p: Northern California's Bay Area Rapid Transit District (BART) said on Thursday it would sign an agreement that should clear the way for its $1.2 billion airport extension project.
"We are the final party to sign this 'terms agreement,' which resulted from negotiations that began last month," BART board president Margaret Pryor said.
Pryor said she would sign the agreement because of a commitment made by San Francisco Mayor Willie Brown that could expedite construction.

The agreement -- which sets out how the airline industry, the airport and BART will work together to get the project built -- should clear the way for federal officials to issue a full funding grant agreement for the project, BART said.
"It is our hope that this will break the log-jam and move us rapidly toward construction," Pryor said.
BART is waiting for a full funding grant agreement for $750 million.
The 8.7-mile, $1.167 billion project would extend BART to San Francisco International Airport.
